Award.AwardTitle: Microscale Reactivity of Trace Elements in Complex Geochemical Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soils supply nutrients to agricultural crops while also preventing toxic substances from entering food and water supplies. This research project is motivated in part by the current mass poisoning of 100 million people in Southern Asia, which is the result of naturally occurring arsenic moving through soils and into drinking water. The research will provide fundamental knowledge about binding of arsenic and other toxic substance in soils, which will help to development better management strategies to protect human health. Investigators will use highly advanced scientific tools coupled with advanced statistical analyses to discover how complicated interactions between different types of soil particles affect binding of toxic substances. The work will help figure out ways to increase binding of toxic substances on soil particles in order to prevent these substances from moving into food and water supplies.

Mining, manufacturing, energy consumption, and agricultural production all release toxic substances into our natural environment. A high standard of living in the U.S. relies on protecting citizens from exposure to unhealthy substances while still advancing technologies that enhance our lives. Soils are arguably the most complicated natural systems at the earth's surface. Precise management of soils is challenging, but also essential for preventing toxic substances from impacting human health. The new knowledge created in this research will support progress of science in soil chemistry and geochemistry. The work will use state-of-the art analytical techniques at DOE National User Facilities and analyze the results using advanced spatial statistical models and uncertainty analysis. Researchers will investigate a new conceptual model for fundamentally understanding how complex interactions between different soil minerals and organic matter regulate toxic substance mobility in natural systems. A new understanding of mechanisms of toxic substance binding in soils will ultimately improve management practices that advance food production in the U.S., while protecting people from toxic substances dispersed in the environment by industrial activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Arsenic is a USEPA priority pollutant and a worldwide toxic element of concern because of its detrimental impacts on human health. This chemical element is responsible for the ongoing poisoning of 100 million people worldwide. Research using state-of-the-art analytical techniques has revealed many details about the way arsenic binds to pure minerals. However, a detailed level of understanding of arsenic binding and immobilization in more complicated systems such as soils and subsurface drinking water aquifers is inhibited by the difficulty of separating effects of minerals, organic matter, and living organisms that occur together as complex mixtures in soils and groundwater aquifers.

 

Our NSF-funded research developed and used novel ulta-high intensity X-rays and highly sophisticated electron microscopy imaging techniques to analyze which elements are involved in arsenic binding and immobilization onto soil particles, which reduces the environmental impacts of this element. Working with statisticians and physical scientists at some of the world?s most advanced research facilities, we developed novel spatial statistical modeling approaches for understanding how arsenic binds into hundreds of thousands of microscale (0.001 mm x 0.001 mm x ~0.02 mm) volumes of soil containing mixtures of chemical elements. Using these advanced chemical imaging techniques, we determined the chemical elements with which arsenic is associated within these microscale (and even smaller) soil volumes, including iron, aluminum, calcium, titanium, manganese, copper, zinc, and nickel. From these analyses coupled with X-ray spectroscopy techniques that provide deeper insights to possible minerals involved in arsenic binding, we showed that arsenic immobilization in soils very likely involves complicated interactions between mixtures of several minerals and other solid particles. We could separate some of these mixture effects to deduce that iron and possibly aluminum oxide minerals are mainly responsible for arsenic binding, but other solids containing the other less abundant elements also tend to enhance arsenic binding by mechanisms that are not yet known.

 

The outcomes of our research provide new insights into the behavior of toxic contaminants in the environment. They also showed that we need to continue research with sophisticated analytical tools to gain even deeper knowledge of contaminant binding in soils to develop ways to better control the impacts of toxic chemicals on human health and natural ecosystems. We also learned that the closer we look at soils with techniques that probe smaller and smaller volumes, the more complicated the systems appear. This aspect of such detailed research presents challenges for using the small-scale research information to develop effective management strategies for the large-scale systems such as fields, landscapes, and waterways.  However, the collective research of scientists working at different spatial scales will provide a foundation for upscaling our molecular-, nano-, and micro-scale knowledge of arsenic binding to understanding immobilization of arsenic and other toxic substances to protect our food and water supplies.
